comments:
I did a simple upgrade of code that works fine in M7/RC0 to RC1 (the product is
platform based).

After the upgrade to RC1, nothing even starts up: I'm now getting exceptions
trying to load a jdom class that log4j uses. I did no configuration or code
change to upgrade from RC0 to RC1..

Did you install RC1 over RC0?
Does this happen in standalone mode, or while selfhosting?

Nope I cleaned the system; there were no remnants of RC0/M7.

This also happens when I add the folder extension (that contain our product) to
a RC1 full Eclipse SDK download (same classloader exception). If I add the exact
same extension to a M7/RC0 Eclipse SDK, everything works fine.

Let me see if I can create a small test plug-in that recreates the issue. It
fails when log4j is trying to parse its configuration file and it loads jdom
to-do so.

I haven't been able to recreate the issue, but here is some progress.

I made one plug-in that has log4j.jar, jdom.jar and a log4j.xml file in the src
folder (plugin configured as 3.1 plugin without a manifest).. In the plugin
class I added a static final Category logger = Category.get....();. By itself,
this seems to work fine in RC0 as well as RC1.

Create a second plug-in that has plug-in one as a dependent. it also adds a
logger  to its plugin class. 

This second plug-in works fine on M7 when I run it in runtime workbench from
where I implemented it, but does not work if I export and add it to the plugins
on either M7/RC0 or RC1. But the class it doesn't find is log4j.Category, so
it's not the same issue. But I think its weird that it works on runtime
workbench and not after you export it....


I'm not sure if this is helpful yet :) I'll see if I can get closer to repro it
using these small dummy plug-ins, but if someone else has any idea to help me
along the way that would be great as well.
lets target this for RC2 to resolve one way or another

Are you setting any of the following properties?

org.osgi.framework.bootdelegation
osgi.java.profile.bootdelegation

The only way I can see this happenning is if the java property 
org.osgi.framework.bootdelegation is not set to '*'.

RE comment 3: this could fail if the log4j.jar is not included in the 
binary.includes list of the build.properties file.  To be sure check 
the "built" plugin to make sure the log4j.jar is included.

Please attach the complete log.  I'm particularly interested in the !SESSION 
entry of the log.  This contains the VM version information.  Are you using a 
1.5 version of the VM?  AFAIK the Sun 1.4 VMs do not contain the 
org.w3c.dom.ranges package

I had to revert my system, but I'm going to do another attempt today. Is there 
any other logging/debugging I can turn on to help? 
 
Is some kind of system var being set then to force  
 
mmoeller@mmoeller:~/Dev/TeamWorks/TeamWorks/KeplerSM/teamworks> /usr/lib/java2/bin/java 
-version 
java version "1.4.2_03" 
Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_03-b02) 
Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.4.2_03-b02, mixed mode)

The curious part of the stack trace is the following:

org.apache.xerces.jaxp.DocumentBuilderImpl.<init>(DocumentBuilderImpl.java:102)
        at
org.apache.xerces.jaxp.DocumentBuilderFactoryImpl.newDocumentBuilder
(DocumentBuilderFactoryImpl.java:88)
        at
org.apache.log4j.xml.DOMConfigurator.doConfigure(DOMConfigurator.java:659)


It looks like you are including the xml-apis.jar and xerces.jar in your 
plugin. is this true?

If you are able to reproduce the error again, please run with the following 
arguments:

eclipse -console -noexit

The failure should still occur with the "-console -noexit" option but the 
osgi> prompt should stay active.  Enter the command "props" to list the 
current java properties.  Enter "exit" at the osgi> prompt to exit the VM.  
Attach the output of the "props" command to this bug along with the full error 
log.  Thanks.

xercessImpl and xml-apis are both a part of the list of runtime jars yes,  
along with log4j, jdom and castor (+ application specific ones including  
weblogic.jar since we talk to weblogic over RMI).  
  
  
Is this potentially the issue? We didn't change anything to upgrade between M7  
and RC1 though. I'm going to retry the upgrade now with your suggestions.  
THanks!

Created an attachment (id=22097)
Errors in RC1

Here is my eclipse.ini as well, but it has the same issues without it (it just
contains some weblogic communication system properties).. Hope this helps.

mmoeller@mmoeller: .. > cat eclipse.ini
-name "TeamWorks Authoring Environment"
-consoleLog
-clean
-vmargs
-Xmx256m
-Djava.naming.factory.initial=weblogic.jndi.WLInitialContextFactory
-Djava.naming.provider.url=t3://mmoeller:7001
-Dcom.lombardisoftware.core.TWEnvironment.environmentName=AUTHORING_ENVIRONMENT

-Dteamworks.applicationServerPlatform=Weblogic 8.1

I look out xercessImpl and xml-apis from the core plug-in and it does kindof
start up (not sure yet what I've broken doing this), but the plug-in at least
loads since I took all logging out of the plugin activator as well.


However Log4j is also still broken, but with a different exception than before.
Seems like Weblogic's Xercess took over and with a different error message not
seeming to handle the url the Eclipse classloader returns (if I read this
right). Not sure if this is even helpful, but thought I might as well paste it
in here:

We can't make sense of what is going on since we always delegate to the
bootclassloader. Could you please provide us a setup to reproduce the problem.

I can't make steps but I'm working on a plug-in that breaks. I cannot give you a
400.000 line commercial product of course that breaks, and its not easy to
recreate this.

I've gotten so far as a smaller plugin (with the same jars and dependencies)
breaks but I'm not getting the same exceptions.

At this point it is the "compatability" plugin in the dependency list that
breaks or unbreaks it. But I think thats for other reasons, but I'm going to
play a little more and see if I can get it to break.

Ok, I found a small plugin that repros this issue. It is still 1.4MB, so I
didn't want to attach it. You can download it from:
 
http://eclipse.moelleryoung.com/PluginWithLog4j_for91755.zip

Tell me if you have any problems with it..


Anyways, the culprint seems to be xercessImpl.jar (or weblogic.jar which also
contains xercess). If xercess is in the plug-in classpath, log4j is not able to
read its configuration file on RC1 (with the exception in the original bug
description). But the same plug-in works fine on M7/RC0. It also works if you
take out the xercessImpl.jar on RC1. That works for this little plug-in but of
course not for our application which relies on xercess.

There must have been a change in the classloaders between RC0 and RC1 regarding
this...
investigating.
Thanks a lot. Let me know if you need anything else from me.

Thank you for your perseverance and providing the example.
We now understand what is going on. Here are some details on the situation and
ways to fix the problem.

Log4j creates a dom parser. To do so XML API uses the context classloader to
find the factory to use. Therefore it discovers the implementation provided by
the xercesImpl.jar and this is fine. However the xercesImpl.jar uses some API
classes that may or may not be in the JRE (in this case the DocumentRange class
is available in IBM JRE but not in the Sun JRE) which results in the
NoClassDefFoundError you've seen.

There are various ways to fix the problem:

1) Ship the proper xmlParserAPI.jar within your plugin. Therefore when the
parser will look for the API classes it will find eventually consult this jar.
Note that this might still cause problems in scenarios where the version of the
xml api provided by the JRE is older than the one you are providing.

2) Don't ship xercesImpl.jar in your plugin. Instead put it and its API in a
plugin of its own so you can refer to it. However you can still encounter the
same kind of problem than in 1) if the version of the xml api provided by the
JRE is older than the one you are providing.

3) Don't ship an XML parser at all, since all 1.4 JRE have them. It you still
need to this, I can only think of two reasons:
   a) You need to run your plugin on a JRE 1.3 or a JRE 1.4. In this case I
recommend that all plugins in need for XML parsing import the packages they need
to run and that you have an XML plugin (the same than in 2)  that exports all
the API packages.
   b) Your plugin needs to run on 2.1 and 3.0, in which case you still want to
have a plugin for XML, but require it optionally.


To summarize, having a copy of a jar in its own plugin is bad. Because it makes
your plugin bigger, because it goes against modularity, and because if multiple
plugin are doing it multiple copy of a same class will exist which could limit
the possible interactions among those plugins.

This doesn't explain why it broke in post-API freeze between two release 
candidates. Something changed in RC1 to break this. 
 
I can't get rid of the xerces code because it is also a part of weblogic which 
we use to talk to weblogic with, you need that jar to talk to Weblogic using 
RMI..

It was working because of a bug that has been fixed between RC0 and RC1: bug #95187.
However, in RC0 the code you gave as example could have never used the xerces parser from your 
plugin, because the parser found was always the one from the bootclassloader.
Given that last point, I'm confused when you say "this jar is needed by weblogic", since in rc0 it seems 
that your app was working and the given jar was ignored. 

For record:
Are you using your own classloader somewhere?
Is the usage of this jar recommended by weblogic itself?

Ah, that bugfix makes sense of things. I dug some more and actually another 
thirdparty plug-in we depend on had just jdom and xercessImpl in it (missing 
the xml-apis where the DocumentRange is). It was actually because of this plug-
in it was failing it looks like. It was working before because it just used 
the bootlevel xml parser as you said.

The reason I said it was required was because on RC1, it would just goto 
weblogic's old implementation of xerces and really mess things up when I took 
it out. But you're right, in Eclipse pre RC1, it wasn't really ever used which 
worked fine as well. On our old swing application this was required to 
override the weblogic implementation (it also ran on pre 1.4).

I still think Bug 85187 sounds way too scary to be changed in release 
candidate mode, since it does in many ways radically change behavior, but I 
can work around it so I guess its ok. Hope noone else has similar problems. 
And maybe this fixes the huge problems we're having trying to communicating 
with Websphere through RMI (only way it could be solved was to put everything 
on the boot classpath. I haven't looked at that myself yet [someone else did 
the websphere work], but this change might be promising in that regard).

Oh I forgot to mention your suggestion 1) worked as soon as I put all the jars 
in a separate plug-in and also took them out of the third party plug-ins we 
were using and made them all depend on plug-ins with the jars in them. Thanks.
